image.altText: A sign in chalk writing that says thank you Mali, goodbye Mr Gupta next to a butcher

props.synopsis: While the SA Premier says a decision to put the Whyalla steelworks into administration is about Australia's steelmaking future, it's also about the many workers, contractors and businesses that rely on it for their livelihoods.

title.children: 'Spare a thought for families in Whyalla': Locals react to steelworks news

image.altText: An adult and children crossing a road in Whyalla.

props.synopsis: The South Australian government has forced the owner of the Whyalla steelworks into administration as it attempts to resolve the crisis at the embattled site.

title.children: SA government forces Whyalla steelworks into administration

image.altText: Two images of a man and a woman yelling and pointing at a healthcare worker at a desk

props.synopsis: New figures from SA Health show the number of code black incidents of violence or threats of aggression has almost doubled over the past year.

title.children: SA regional hospitals hit with huge increase in violent incidents

image.altText: Elderly people, faces unseen, sitting side by side in chairs.

props.synopsis: A wedding ring and a gold watch were among the items Teresa Murray stole from her clients, some of whom suffered from mental impairments.

title.children: No jail for aged care worker who stole jewellery, cash from clients

image.altText: A woman in pink glasses sits on a pink couch

props.synopsis: Media coverage of the Adelaide Fringe is often centred on box office sales, but what's often overlooked is the millions of dollars in backroom deals that secure tours for local acts.

title.children: Adelaide Fringe Festival a honey pot for local acts going international

image.altText: New Royal Adelaide Hospital building site Feb 19, 2015

props.synopsis: Almost eight years after it opened, a public hospital once branded Australia's most-expensive building continues to cost taxpayers, with more than $20 million spent last financial year alone on a long-running legal battle between its builder and the South Australian Government.

title.children: Royal Adelaide Hospital legal battle leaves taxpayers with $20 million bill

image.altText: An overhead view of a mine site with large piles of soil and the outback landscape in the background.

props.synopsis: Miners were using a commonly-used chemical to stabilise ground in the Perilya Southern Operations mine when it ignited and caused a fire with potentially toxic fumes.

title.children: Regulator probes how chemical started underground fire at Broken Hill mine

image.altText: One of two sheep that were found along an Adelaide road.

props.synopsis: After an appeal for public assistance, police say they have identified the owner of two sheep who surprised drivers and stopped traffic at a major intersection in suburban Adelaide.

title.children: Sheep mystery as fleecy pair stop peak-hour traffic in Adelaide

image.altText: The police running sheet and poster relating to the missing Beaumont children.

props.synopsis: This weekend, another search for the remains of the Beaumont children will be undertaken at a former foundry site in Adelaide's west. For almost 60 years, the disappearance of nine-year-old Jane, seven-year-old Arnna and four-year-old Grant has baffled detectives.

title.children: Disappearance of Beaumont children 'fundamentally changed society'

image.altText: A woman leans against an older man in a hat and striped shirt and an older woman wearing glasses, all smiling.

props.synopsis: Coroners will begin assessing if a learner driver who caused the death of three people was fit to drive. The 16-year-old was found guilty of careless driving, but not guilty of the more serious crime of causing death by dangerous driving.

title.children: Inquest to see if learner driver who caused triple fatal was fit to drive

image.altText: A paper sign taped to a black fence telling people about a childcare centre being shut down

props.synopsis: Genius Childcare at Blair Athol will be permanently shut down by its operators at the end of the month, despite being permitted to reopen by education regulators after addressing cleanliness concerns.

title.children: Adelaide childcare centre hit with cleanliness concerns to be shut down

image.altText: A man with beard wearing white t-shirt with graphic in a backyard

props.synopsis: Rodney Clough has been sentenced to more than three years in jail for submerging his nephew's face in a sink filled with hot water. Taking into account time served, he is now eligible to apply for release on parole.

title.children: 'Frustration does not provide an excuse': Man who scalded 2yo with hot water sentenced

image.altText: Behind a prison fence protestors waving white and blue Israeli flags, with an orange sign in Hebrew visible

props.synopsis: The reservists are accused of severe abuse of the man, who suffered serious injuries as a result of his treatment behind bars

title.children: Five Israeli soldiers charged over horrific abuse of Palestinian man at infamous jail

image.altText: A doctor in a lab undertaking IVF treatment.

props.synopsis: Patients have told the ABC they spent days trying to get in touch with their local clinic and in some cases, this meant time-critical testing couldn't go ahead.

title.children: Genea patients frustrated by lack of communication amid data breach

image.altText: Kaitlyn Dever recreates Belle Gibson's infamous 60 Minutes interview, with a ponytail and pink jumper.

props.synopsis: If we want to avoid the potentially fatal sway of canny fabulists like Belle Gibson, the answer is not to ridicule patients but to elevate science, to put more money into cancer research.

title.children: To counter fabulists like Belle Gibson we must elevate science, fund cancer research

image.altText: A woman wearing glasses, in a Sydney CBD office building, looking out the window.

props.synopsis: The ACCC will increase its scrutiny of Australia's supermarkets, retailers, airlines and essential services as a lack of competition exacerbates the cost of living crisis, while its chair Gina Cass-Gottlieb worries there could be an uptick in financial scams as US President Donald Trump relaxes cryptocurrency regulations.

title.children: ACCC boss warns of crypto 'horror scenarios' and lack of competition in Australian aviation

image.altText: Maura Elaripe

props.synopsis: The Asia Pacific region has the largest HIV epidemic outside of Africa and advocates fear an end to US aid could make matters worse.

title.children: 'The community is panicking': Fears over Trump's cuts to aid programs

image.altText: A young pale man in a blue T-shirt speaks in front of a blurry background with the letters AI projected on a wall.

props.synopsis: Meta says its new underwater cable project is longer than the Earth's circumference — and one expert says it's "very feasible".

title.children: Can Meta build an undersea cable spanning the entire  world?

image.altText: Close up of Brittany Higgins with her head down.

props.synopsis: The judge found David William Wonnocott, who made the threats over social media, had disregarded previous warnings, leniency, and paths to rehabilitation provided by the court.

title.children: Man jailed over online threats to kill Brittany Higgins and her partner

image.altText: Palmer scratches his head.

props.synopsis: Entering their 70s, Clive Palmer and Pauline Hanson attempted to unify their parties to capture more disaffected voters. But the deal fell apart.

title.children: Clive Palmer, Pauline Hanson trade barbs over failed bid to unify parties

image.altText: Ryuji Kimura was caught by police

props.synopsis: A 25-year-old man has been sentenced to 10 years in prison, after attempting to murder Japan's former Prime Minister Fumio Kishida with a homemade pipe bomb two years ago.

title.children: Man who attacked former Japanese prime minister with pipe bomb sentenced

image.altText: A woman standing and smiling widely in the foyer of a theatre.

props.synopsis: Police have declared a major investigation into the death of 40-year-old Veronica Wellings, involving the major crime and domestic violence units, after her death at Darwin's largest hospital on Monday.

title.children: Woman who died in 'suspicious' circumstances identified as NT singer

image.altText: A woman smiles at an event in a strappless dress, diamond necklace and her hair in a loose bun

props.synopsis: Meghan, Duchess of Sussex, announced a rebrand of her lifestyle range, with the label's new website featuring a rare photo of Princess Lilibet.

title.children: Duchess of Sussex announces rebrand with rare photo of Princess Lilibet

image.altText: James Marape salutes as he walks past defence personnel outside parliament house.

props.synopsis: Australia and PNG are to begin negotiations on a defence treaty in a move that could have major implications for national security and the Pacific's strategic landscape.

title.children: Australia and PNG to begin negotiations on new defence treaty

image.altText: Australian actor Guy Pearce having his photo taken at a movie event

props.synopsis: Guy Pearce chokes up during a new interview while recalling unpleasant experiences working with Kevin Spacey on Oscar-winning 1997 film LA Confidential.

title.children: Kevin Spacey says Guy Pearce is 'not a victim' after actor's allegations

image.altText: John Setka sitting behind a number of microphones at a Melbourne media conference.

props.synopsis: The Fair Work Ombudsman has kicked off legal action against former union heavyweight John Setka, alleging he tried to coerce the AFL into sacking its head of umpiring.

title.children: Fair Work Ombudsman launches legal action against former CFMEU boss

image.altText: Dozens of dark-coloured, medium-sized whales lying on a beach.

props.synopsis: Authorities say 90 false killer whales will be euthanased following unsuccessful refloating attempts. It follows the mass-stranding of a group of more than 150 false killer whales near Arthur River in Tasmania.

title.children: 90 false killer whales to be euthanased after unsuccessful refloating

image.altText: Pope Francis grinning while wearing white robes and a silver Catholic cross chain and waving with his left hand

props.synopsis: A chest scan taken at Rome's Gemelli hospital shows the pontiff has developed bilateral pneumonia, after being treated earlier for asthmatic bronchitis and a complex respiratory infection.

title.children: Pope has pneumonia in both lungs, Vatican says

image.altText: Sue and Lloyd Clarke

props.synopsis: Coercive control will soon be a criminal offence in Queensland and other states are being urged to follow suit.

title.children: Five years since Hannah Clarke's murder her parents beg governments to listen

image.altText: Snapchat icon on a smartphone screen.

props.synopsis: Jacob Keele, 22, has been sent to prison after paying underage girls to send him explicit photos and videos, and threatening to leak them online.

title.children: Man jailed after using Snapchat to target girls for explicit images

image.altText: A$AP Rocky celebrates out the window of a car as he wins trial

props.synopsis: The verdict follows a trial during which the alleged victim, A$AP Relli, testified that Rocky fired two shots from a handgun at him.

title.children: A$AP Rocky found not guilty in shooting trial

image.altText: A concrete building reading "Law Courts of the Australian Capital Territory", with the Australian, ACT and Aboriginal flags.

props.synopsis: Angus McKay, 32, will serve two months in prison of an 18-month jail sentence, in what is the first sentencing in Canberra following a major review of sexual assault cases.

title.children: Families clash outside Canberra court after man jailed for raping former friend

image.altText: A man in period costume aims a crossbow towards the camera.

props.synopsis: Claes Bang, the Danish star of the theatrical action epic, talks about taking on the mantle of the famous, apple-shooting, anti-colonial folk hero.

title.children: William Tell shot an apple off his son's head for one tragic reason
